turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Sergeant?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Yessir.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: You ever reflect how this big explosion in dead women coincides with the flowering of women's lib?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Yessir.  I have reflected on that, sir.  Which explains my gushing deference to you, sir.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Don't swear at me because we got problems.  I'm just giving you the news.  I went to a Catholic school; I'll tell you what they teach.  On the knuckles they teach.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Who've I got to beat up except the messenger?  Does this give us anything to go on?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: I'm checking out anybody who lives like DeSalvo.  Records of arrests for rape, especially by a man wearing green.  Checking out psychiatric hospitals for his personality profile.  Cross check- ing names from arrests for sexual offenses, public fondling.  If they've got a German wife.  We can keep cops working on this kind of junk for years, and this guy's going to hit again, soon.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: I know.  Get out here.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: So.  Do we tell the media and hope for somebody to come forward with information?

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Or for some new nutcase to copycat the copycat.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Oh, maaaaan?!

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: What?  I talk like a cop, this is the way I talk.  I can't believe this guy.  Saks.  He's a Deputy Assistant Director of the F.B.I. "Let me help you!"

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: We could use a little help.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: With the F.B.I. there's no such thing as a little help.  They bury you with help.  Explain to me about this virus, no don't tell me about the virus.  Thing is, you saw it, the pictures.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: So what have we got?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: It's not the same guy.  It should be a self-solver.  No bow around the neck, left and body outdoors, completely different.  The others were housewives, secretaries, he talked his way inside, killed them in their own living room or bed- or bathroom.  This one didn't have a husband or a boyfriend, no family, temp waitress, 3 arrests for misdemeanor dope offenses, DUI, asphyxiation probably from a plastic bag over her head.  Sexually assaulted.  The others weren't molested that way.  We're waiting for the sperm tests...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Christ.  How old are you?  You sure you want to be in this line of work?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: You're damn right I do.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Okay, now what about your sidekick punching my favorite detective? What the hell is going on?  You got no discipline in your operation.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: I'm sorry it had to come to your attention.  I am dealing with it.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Where you going?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Helen Hudson...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: What the hell you need her for?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Because I think I'm wrong.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: M.J., I'm going to have to borrow Ruben.  The alien-smuggling thing in Chinatown is going down tomorrow night and Jack's kid got hit by a car.  I gotta give Ruben to Nikko.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: What does this mean?  Now we got the FBI, my team is expendable? I'm working my ass off, is anybody listening?  Why Ruben, anyway?  He and Nikko don't even get on together...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Teach both of them a lesson in cooperation and self-discipline.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: If this is a first step in kicking me off the case, just tell me, to my face, sir, don't waste time being diplomatic.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Just, I need results.  And -- I am short-handed.  Who else am I gonna give him?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Give him <u>that</u>pompous son of a bitch.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: I didn't want the Illigals, I wanted just the bastards dumping them in the harbor.  What's keeping those bums at Immigration?  Nightmare in here...

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: I gotta have Ruben, and a...

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: The prowler in Hudson's apartment turns out to have a meeting with a suspect...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: You got a suspect...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: How'd you get in on the deal?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: I'm gonna drop charges on the break-and-enter at Hudson's...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: You have no authority to make a deal like that.  That' s for the D.A...

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Or the F.B.I.?

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Saks.  If he knew you did that! They're all asking me, 'what is she doing,' as it is.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Give me Ruben back...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Nikko?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: You want mine, too?  You take his, you take mine.  I'm the one fucked it up...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: So I'm maybe gonna lose three good cops?  You fucked up on this occasion, but don't be so hard on yourself.  There's something I want you to think about.  The book says if you use your gun, use it to kill, that's what it's meant to do. You tried to pick this punk off with fancy shooting, to keep him alive.  To what end?  You're not willing to kill, you can't be a cop.  Go get drunk.  I am.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: That was Bundy.  He killed forty of them, identical, long hair, parted in the middle, alike as Barbie dolls.  ...this is hopeless.  Let's try to get time for a police spokesman to appear on college radio and TV hookups and broadcast a warning?

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: "Spokes<u>person</u>."

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: She's in no shape to give her statement tonight...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: No, she can come in tomorrow... gonna want to know a lot of things...

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: I just got here myself, Susan.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: ...confirm this third murder adds up to a pattern?  Do we have a serial killer on the loose in the city?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: I just got here.  Talk to you later...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: ... third Bay Area woman has been strangled, but the police continue to deny that this is the work of one killer.  Lt. Thomas Quinn declares that the murders will be treated as unrelated crimes, unless new evidence...

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: You messed with the evidence.

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: Detective Niccoletti?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What's this about the Boston Strangler, M.J.?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Inspector, will you confirm somebody is copying the Boston Strangler?  This is the fourth, is that correct?

turns.speaker: M.J.
turns.text: We're going to review all the evidence carefully before making any statement...

turns.speaker: NIKKO
turns.text: He's not treating her right...

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: She left you, Nikko.  She's not your responsibility.  She takes very good care of herself.  If she wants to romance the kid, it ain't your business.  Your business is to snap out of it.

turns.speaker: NIKKO
turns.text: We were together six years, sir!

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Don't give me six years!  You never divorced Patty, did you?  So what'd you expect from M.J.?

turns.speaker: NIKKO
turns.text: She knows I'm Catholic!  She never mentioned divorce!  Not once!

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: Then you shoulda known she wasn't buying.  She was just long-term leasing' you.  Ah, Nickie.  Except for that rare twenty-second twitch, there ain't nothin' about sex I don't hate. But of course, I'm Irish.  Plus I got <u>real</u> problems.  I'm worried I might have to put you in over M.J.  There's something going on here, the Commissioner is targeting her now, I can't leave a woman in that position.  But the thing is, how can I move <u>you</u> in, if you go on acting like a teenage asshole?

turns.speaker: NIKKO
turns.text: I don't want the job.  Don't do that to her.  She's worked too damned hard for it.

turns.speaker: QUINN
turns.text: What's going down with the sting in Chinatown?  That gonna be off your plate in a week or what?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: Put in the Kevin Costner.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why don't we save it for later? It's almost time for Letterman.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: You know I don't like to watch talk shows by myself.  Where're you?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: See, now you've annoyed her.  You know she doesn't like you to touch me.  Does she, widdle wee fing!  Wuhve you so much!  Did you feed her?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes, I fed her.  If she says she's hungry, she's lying to you.  Again.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: She doesn't lie!  You sure you fed her?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: She lies all the time.  Why would I say I fed her if I didn't?

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: That's what I don't know.  Why would you lie?  That's the problem... I can't understand why anyone would lie.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Where were you?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: In the private aircraft hangar. Anybody could have walked in.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Did you come?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No. What about your camera girl? Did she come?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: We were interrupted. I had to go back to the set...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Poor darling.  What can I do about Karen? How can I arrange to have her seduce me? She desperately needs a conquest.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I've been thinking about that, about you and Karen.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: There, that's better.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Not a lot of action here.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: They consider this to be the airport hospital. This ward is reserved for air- crash victims. The beds are kept waiting.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: If I groundloop during my flying lesson on Saturday you might wake up and find me next to you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I'll listen for you buzzing over.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Is that a gift from Wendel? It has an aeronautical feel to it.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Yes. From Wendel. To celebrate, the license approval for our air-charter firm. I forgot to tell you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: That's going well, then.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Well, yes.  You're getting out of bed tomorrow. They want you to walk.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: The other man, the dead man, his wife is a doctor - Dr. Helen Remington. She's here, somewhere. As a patient, of course. Maybe you'll find her in the hallways tomorrow on your walk.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: And her husband? What was he?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: He was a chemical engineer with a food company.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Where's the car?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Outside in the visitors, car park.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What!? They brought the car here?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: My car, not yours. Yours is a complete wreck. The police dragged it to the pound behind the station.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Have you seen it?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: The sergeant asked me to identify it. He didn't believe you'd gotten out alive.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: It's about time.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: It is?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: After being bombarded endlessly by road- safety propaganda, it's almost a relief to have found myself in-an actual accident.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Minute flecks were spattered across the seat and steering wheel. The instrument panel was buckled inwards, cracking the clock and the speedometer dials. The cabin was deformed, and there was dust and glass and plastic flakes everywhere inside. The carpeting was damp and stank of blood and other body and machine fluids.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You should have gone to the funeral.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I wish I had. They bury the dead so quickly - they should leave them lying around for months.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What about his wife? The woman doctor? Have you visited her yet?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: No, I couldn't. I feel too close to her.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Renata tells me you're going to rent a car.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I can't sit on this balcony forever. I'm beginning to feel like a potted plant.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: How can you drive? James... your legs. You can Barely walk.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Is the traffic heavier now? There seem to be three times as many cars as there were before the accident.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I've never really noticed. Is Renata going with you?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I thought she might come along. Handling a car again might be more tiring than I imagine.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'm amazed that she'll let you drive her.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You're not envious?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Maybe I am a little.  James, I've got to leave for the office. Are you going to be all right?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: He must have tucked a lot of women in that huge car of his. It's like a bed on wheels. It must smell of semen...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: It does.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Do you find him attractive?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: He's very pale. Covered with scars.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Would you like to tuck him, though? In that car?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No. But when he's in that car...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Have you seen his penis?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I think it's badly scarred too. From a motorcycle accident.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: Is he circumcised? Can you imagine what his anus is like? Describe it to me. Would you like to sodomize him? Would you like to put your penis right into his anus, thrust it up his anus? Tell me, describe it to me. Tell me what you would do. How would you kiss him in that car? Describe how you'd reach over and unzip his greasy jeans, then take out his penis. Would you kiss it or suck it right away? Which hand would you hold it in? Have you ever sucked a penis? Do you know what semen tastes like? Have you ever tasted semen? Some semen is saltier than others. Vaughan's semen must be very salty...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: They're questioning Vaughan about an accident near the airport. Some pedestrian... they think he was run over intentionally.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Vaughan isn't interested in pedestrians.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: You'd better drive him. He's a bit shaky. I'll follow in my car. Where is yours?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: At home. I couldn't face all this traffic.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'd better come with you, then. Are you sure you can drive?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I thought that was you, up there.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: My last lesson's next week.  James... my car...

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I wasn't driving. I'd left the car in the parking lot at the airport. Could it have been deliberate?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: One of your suitors?

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: One of my suitors.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: The traffic... where is everyone? They've all gone away.

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: I'd like to go back. James...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Not yet. It's only beginning.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I think he'll be waiting for us at the airport

turns.speaker: CATHERINE
turns.text: James.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: After this sort of thing, how do people manage to look at a car, let alone drive one?  I'm trying to find Charles's car.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: It's not here. Maybe the police are still holding it. Their forensic people...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: They said it was here. They told me this morning.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I don't think we should have come here. I'm surprised the police don't make it more difficult.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Were you badly hurt? I think we saw each other at the hospital.  I don't want the car. In fact, I was appalled to find that I have to pay a small fee to have it scrapped.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Can I give you a lift?  I somehow find myself driving again.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You haven't told me where we're going.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Haven't I? To the airport, if you could.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: The airport? Why? Are you leaving?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Not yet - though not soon enough for some people, I've already found. A death in the doctor's family makes the patients doubly uneasy.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I take it you're not wearing white to reassure them.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I'll wear a bloody kimono if I want to.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: So - why the airport?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I work in the immigration department there.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Do you want a cigarette? I started to smoke at the hospital. It's rather stupid of me.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Look at all this traffic. I'm not sure I can deal with it.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: It's much worse now. You noticed that, did you? The day I left the hospital I had the extraordinary feeling that all these cars were gathering for some special reason I didn't understand. There seemed to be ten times as much traffic.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Are we imagining it?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I've found that I enjoy burying myself in heavy traffic. I like to look at it. Yesterday I hired a taxi driver to drive me around for an hour. "Anywhere", I said.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: We sat in B massive traffic jam under an off-ramp. I don't think we moved more than fifty yards.  I'm thinking of taking up a new job with the Road Research Laboratory. They need a medical officer. The salary is larger something I've got to think about now. There's a certain moral virtue in being materialistic, I'm beginning to feel. Well, it's a new approach for me, in any case.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: The Road Research Laboratory? Where they simulate car crashes?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Isn't that rather too close...?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: That's the point. Besides, I know I can give something now that I wasn't remotely aware of before. It's not a matter of duty so much as of commitment.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Who is that? The announcer. Do I know him?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: That's Vaughan. He talked to you at the hospital.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Oh yes. I thought he was a medical photographer, doing some sort of accident research. He wanted every conceivable detail about our crash.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: When I first met Vaughan, he was a specialist in international computerized traffic systems. I don't know what he is now.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Is this part of the act or are they really hurt?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I don't know. You can never be sure with Vaughan. This is his show.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Please finish your story.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: The junior pathologist at Ashford Hospital. Then the husband of a colleague of mine, then a trainee radiologist, then the service manager at my garage.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: And you had sex with all of these men in cars? Only in cars?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes. I didn't plan it that way.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: And did you fantasize that Vaughan was photographing all these sex acts? As though they were traffic accidents?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Yes.  They felt like traffic accidents.

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: Are we allowed to park here?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: I'm sure the police would make an exception in your case.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: There's still a patch of blood there on the road. Did you see it?

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: I saw the blood. It looks like motor oil.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You were the last one I saw just before the accident. Do you remember? We made love.

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: Are you still involving me in your crash?

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: Can you drive?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: I can drive.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: A complimentary ticket for a special stunt-driving exhibition. Definitely not part of the big auto show. There's a map in the packet and a note requesting you be discrete about the location.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Really? What kind of exhibition is it?

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: I suspect it involves reenactments of famous car crashes. You know, Jayne Mansfield, James Dean, Albert Camus...

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: Serious. But you'll have to take your new friend, the female crash-test dummy. She dropped it off for you.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You're not jealous, are you? You have to understand... Helen and I had this strange, intense... experience together.

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: What does he want from you?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Hard to say.

turns.speaker: RENATA
turns.text: I'm going to leave now. Do you want a lift?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: No, thanks. I'll go with Vaughan.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: Crash victim?

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Why are the police taking this all so seriously?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: It's not the police. It's the Department of Transport. Internal politics. It's a joke. They have no idea who we really are

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Do you live here? With Seagrave?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I live in my car. This is my workshop.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What exactly is your project, Vaughan? ~ book of crashes? A medical study? A sensational documentary? Global traffic?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: It's something we're all intimately involved in: The reshaping of the human body by modern technology.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I've always wanted to drive a crashed car.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: You could get your wish at any moment.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: No, I mean a crash with a history. Camus' Facel Vega, or Nathaniel Nest's station wagon, Grace Kelly's Rover 3500. Fix it just enough to get it rolling. Don't clean it, don't touch anything else.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Is that why you drive this car? I take it that you see Kennedy's assassination as a special kind of car-crash?

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: The case could be made.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: It's very... satisfying. I'm not sure I understand why.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: It's the future, Ballard, and you're already part of it. For the first time, a benevolent psychopathology beckons towards us. For example, the car crash is a fertilizing rather than a destructive event - a liberation of sexual energy that mediates the sexuality of those who have died with an intensity impossible in any other form. To fully understand that, and to live that... that is my project.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: What about the reshaping of the human body by modern technology? I thought that was your project.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: A crude sci-fi concept that floats on the surface and doesn't threaten anybody. I use it to test the resilience of my potential partners in psychopathology.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: He must have driven through a pool of blood. If the police stop you again, they may impound the car while they have the blood analyzed. Vaughan kneels beside him and inspects the smears of blood.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: You're right, Ballard. There's an all- night car-wash in the airport service area.

turns.speaker: VAUGHAN
turns.text: I need to see you, Ballard. I need to talk to you about the project.

turns.speaker: JAMES
turns.text: Where are you?

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Hello, Letitia. I'm Dr. Emlee, and I have some questions to ask you...

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I did this already.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: It's hospital policy...

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: I'm the only doctor making rounds this morning.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Well, I don't have hallucinations. Honest.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: This doctor, was he tall, with dark hair?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Yeah, and a dimple.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: I'm afraid Lhe's not a doctor.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Psychologist, therapist, whatever.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Patient.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: What kind of place is this?

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: I apologize for the inconvenience, but I must ask you some...

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I want to see my mother immediately.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: We discourage family visits for the first 48 hours after an emotional trauma like the kind you've experienced.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I don't think you understand.    I won't wait.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Do we have to talk about this?

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: I think in the spirit of group therapy, it's beneficial for each of us to open ourselves up to the others.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: The medicine's still bothering me. It feels like I have cotton wrapped around my brain.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: We'll see about adjusting the dosage if that doesn't clear in the next  How are other things going?

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: The question, Letty, is how are you feeling?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I miss Beast a lot, too.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I couldn't really say anything because of that fraternizing rule.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Well, Letty, this does present a liability issue for the hospital.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I'm a grown woman, Dr. Emlee.   I can take care of myself.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: What about Michael? Do you know the extent of his...

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I know Michael's a schizophrenic, and Mrs. Hallstrom's manic- depressive, and John Lockyer has episodes of psychosis, and I heard a rumor that you suffer from delusions of grandeur.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Go ahead and put the guard back up, Letty. But you need to know what you're dealing with.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I don't need a lecture.   I care about Michael.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Then that's even more reason to listen. Look, schizophrenics tend to withdraw from reality. They experience emotional disturbances that result in personality changes.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Look, I know he's almost through with treatment here. And, he's on medication.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Drugs can help suppress symptoms. But lots of patients stop taking them when they're on their own because the side effects are so harsh.  And, Michael's condition is often worsened by periods of stress. He's been in and out of...

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I don't want to hear anymore.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: First you tell me to do what I want to, then you tell me to stop.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: All I want you to do is think about what's best for you. Really think about it.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: But what I really can't believe is that I'm starting to actually miss work.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Have you been in contact with the principal about your job?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I thought about calling, but I want to wait until I know when I'll be out.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Then, you should call.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: I think it's about that time, Letty. The charges against you have been dropped, the drugs have evened out and you seem to be dealing with your life quite well.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Are you saying I'm through with therapy?

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: So, we'll meet every Tuesday and Friday. And if you have any kind of emergency, you can page me.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: OK, good. That's good. Thanks an awful lot for everything, and for coming down here to see me off.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: It was just a little going-away gesture.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I have a going-away gesture for you, too.

turns.speaker: DR. EMLEE
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: What's up with you?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Me? Nothing. Tell me more about the job.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Just go ahead and tell us.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: There's nothing to tell.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: No, really. Tell me about the promotion.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Well, my theory is that people can really enjoy math, but they lose interest...

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: She says she won't even come if Dad brings Monica.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Mom won't miss your wedding. She'll come around. I promise she will.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I'll talk to her, and to Dad, too.  A few wisely-chosen guilt tactics and they'll be ours.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Maybe if we had them both to dinner or something.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: You always throw the best dinner parties, Letty.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Oh, wait a minute, now I see where you're going.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Please, Letty.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Mom and Dad? At dinner together? Are you crazy?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Maybe, though. Maybe it would work. I could throw you an engagement party maybe.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: You know what, Ruthie? I better get back to my class, OK?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: And the party?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Yeah, it'll be fun.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Where's the old bag I sometimes call Mommy?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: She said she'd be here at 10.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What do you think of this one?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I'd have to see it on.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Things have been kind of stressful lately.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: But everything's OK?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Yeah, everything's under control.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What about the engagement party?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Everything's ready for tomorrow night--except the artillery.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Thanks so much for planning it, Letty. Jake's really looking forward to it.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What about this one?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: You look beautiful.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Truly.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Hi, Mom.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Look, Mom, I think I've found the dress.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Go on, Letty. I want to see it on you.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Do you think I should?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: How can I help?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Paul, can you hand me the olives? Ruth, I need you to, what was it?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What about the souffle?    Has that gone in?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Fuck me.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What's all the dreck?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Sage, rosemary...  Les Herbes.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: It'll be fine.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: No, no. They've got to be Puglia olives, packed in a light brine with a flavor that doesn't overpower the palate.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Letty, dinner's almost ready.   The souffle...

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I'll be back before you can say souffle.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I can't believe you finally gave me the shirt.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Loaned you. And it's only 'til you get out of here.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: That settles it. I'm never leaving.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: I can hardly wait 'til you're free. Planning the wedding without you has been a disaster.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: You're slowing.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Mom and I fought for 20 minutes over whether we should go with ecru invitations or brilliant white.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Ecru.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: And then the gold scroll or the black Romanesque print?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Do we have to talk wedding details?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Oh, no, of course not.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: What's his name, Letty?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I didn't say...

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I don't think people even noticed. I thought the ceremony was perfect.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: That's thanks to all your help.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: You did the right thing.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I ruined your wedding night.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Oh, Ruthie, what am I going to do?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: You don't have to make any decisions tonight.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: But what am I going to do?

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: Do you want to go see him? I'll take you if you want to go.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I can't.    I can't see him there.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I was so sure. I really thought it would work.  We have plans, Ruth.

turns.speaker: RUTH
turns.text: I know.    I know.

turns.speaker: MRS. MAYER
turns.text: How wonderful, darling.  What does that mean for you?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: I'll be running it three days a week, and...

turns.speaker: MRS. MAYER
turns.text: Will you get time off to do that?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Not now, but maybe later, if they like the program.

turns.speaker: MRS. MAYER
turns.text: Are you sure, Dear?

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Come on.

turns.speaker: MRS. MAYER
turns.text: My goodness. A wedding.      My goodness.

turns.speaker: LETTY
turns.text: Wow.   Congratulations.
